>Free beginner resources to get started with HTML, CSS, JavaScript and PHP
https://eloquentjavascript.net/Eloquent_JavaScript.pdf - A modern introduction to JavaScript
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn - A good starting point to learn about web dev fundamentals
https://javascript.info/ - Quite a good JS tutorial
https://www.theodinproject.com - Curriculum including HTML/CSS/JS, and either Ruby on Rails + SQL, or Node.js + MongoDB
https://fullstackopen.com/en/ - Requires you to have basic web dev, db and git knowledge
https://flexboxfroggy.com/ and https://cssgridgarden.com/ - Learn flex/grid in CSS
https://phptherightway.com/ - A decent PHP resource
https://www.phptutorial.net - A PHP tutorial

https://github.com/bradtraversy/design-resources-for-developers

>All useful documentation in one place
https://devdocs.io

>Need help? Create an example and post the link
https://jsfiddle.net - if you need help with HTML/CSS/JS
https://3v4l.org - if you need help with PHP/HackLang
https://codesandbox.io - if you need help with React/Angular/Vue

>>90925989
>3600-16-18-18
Okay there's some chance it won't work with XMP because that's relatively fast and relatively tight for dual rank operation.
If it runs XMP, great. If it doesn't, you will need to manually tune it. First try increasing the voltage a little with the basic XMP timings. Go up to 1.4V or so. If that fails, drop the clock back to 3200 @ 1.35V and increase it from there.
Also, do remember that dual rank increases performance approximately equivalent to +400MHz effective clock. So if you end up stuck at 3200 you're not actually losing much, if any, performance.

For my fellow pyg/tavern niggas, here's a tip.
When you send an empty message, tavern recognizes the last bot message as a continuation. Therefore, what you can do is simply edit the bot's response to start with something you want it to say (say just a single action), then send a blank to have it continue the message. Far more powerful than just putting in asterisks in your own message what you want the bot to do. You can really guide the AI in the right direction just by giving it little pushes like this

I have a training question.
https://rentry.org/simplified-embed-training#4-prune-tags-that-describe-your-character-using-boorudatasettagmanager
>This is the tedious part. Remove all descriptions of your character that you want the AI to learn. For example, if your character is always wearing black gloves and you want the AI to learn that, remove it from all images with the delete button on the far right. If your character always has an ahoge/short hair/black hair/fang, remove those tags from all images.

https://rentry.org/2chAI_LoRA_Dreambooth_guide_english#general-advice
>And all captions should have a keyword describing this character/person. For example, 1.txt: photo of JohnFriend, jacket, jeans; 2.txt: photo of JohnFriend, shorts, t-shirt. You will use the tag JohnFriend to call this person in the prompt. The same works for anime models - in this case it will be the name of the character. For example, 1girl, shiina mayuri, short hair, green eyes, etc. Call out with shiina mayuri, respectively.

So, what is the correct way to train a character and to call out this character in prompts?

Thoughts on the D programming language?
Theoretically, it has something for everyone: you can use the GC or not, it lets you do "unsafe" things if you want it to allow you or not, it has functional programming (through function purity and transitive immutability) and they're experimenting with adding an ownership/borrowing system similar to Rust.
Do you think it's doing too much? Ignoring the fact that there aren't that many resources for learning the language and it doesn't have the frameworks or libraries of other languages, would you ever consider using this language at work or for your own projects?

posts.com:
>>90925749
Theres a lot of ways to go about this and I've spent a lot of time on it. I'd say MPD is well suited to this use-case. It has builtin HTTP streaming capability and can also work with Icecast. The HTTP stream will just put a stream to a TCP port whereas Icecast will give you a minimal web interface and will let you open the stream in shoutcast clients. However, one complication is that its not enough to have just the stream. You'll also need to find an MPD client to control your playlist and skip back and forth.

If you want to setup a web radio, a good program is Liquidsoap, which is like an automation program for music. That is not without its complications too but when its working its fucking cool to tune in to a radio station that only has music you like.

>>90924453
I used git via the CLI for years, never had an issue. On a whim I decided to the Git client built into PyCharm. It was just OK, didn't feel any reason to use over the CLI. Some time later I decided to try Sublime Merge in one of my not uncommon periods of hysteria for Sublime Text. I loved it. It's fast. Most of its commands map directly to CLI commands (and hovering over the button tells you the command). Almost entirely usable from keyboard. Excellent diff visualizations. Nothing not to like. Except... it doesn't seem to do well with HUGE repos. Opening the Unreal Engine 5.1 source (after cloning), it just sits unresponsively for many minutes. Last I tried was three or four months ago, so maybe they've fixed it. Overall though I highly recommend. I even decided to buy a license to support, thought it's usable without one.

Copyright came from Britain and was created as a “compromise” and “improvement” over the Stationers.
The Stationers were basically a nationalized monopoly on everything ever printed in the English language.
They were disbanded but “copyright” was invented in its place for authors who were to used to the old system.
Basically a temporary monopoly.
You get to larp as if you are your own stationer, for a few years.

Interestingly enough the US had no copyright for the first decade or so it existed.
Then some artists lobbied the government to copy what Britain had done (hah, copy, how ironic)
So the US adopted the “English standard” of 14 years legal monopoly on every work made by a us citizen.
Since 1800s it’s been a constant stream of artists and art corporations slowly but surely lobbying the government to extend the term, creeping up ever higher to the 100 bazillion years or whatever it is now.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90890307
>A negative ion air purifier is one that causes particles in the air to gain a negative charge, which makes them bind together with positively charged particles and fall out of the air or stick to positively charged objects in the room. They are not as effective as air purifiers based on HEPA filter technology.
Assuming it actually works, it basically applies a voltage across the sides. If it's battery powered it should have a positive and negative electrode, if it's usb or plugged in it may just be positive and use earth as negative.
The idea is it charges particles and they then stick to the ground or things in your room. That way it's not in the air (probably good), but it's on other stuff and may get back into the air eventually. Not the greatest technology, but in theory it does work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90883421
>My room is empty and barren and I would like to change that by ordering 50 kgs of chinese garbage. Does anyone have suggestions for what I should buy, I'm going for the 'chinatown souvenir shop' look. Only things in my cart right now are this and a CoD MW2 CD rug
Trinkets and souvenirs are hard to suggest. Look around for what appeals to you.
As for proper things that I got from Ali that actually made my room nicer:
- Led strips, preferably Bluetooth or WLAN compatible. It's a bit basic, but I like the look anyways. Attach to the back or underside of a desk/shelf for indirect light.
- "Fairy lights" give a comfy winter feeling. I have one around my desk and a solar one in my plants at the window. Even got one on the balcony.
- a led strip with a movement sensor under the bed so you can turn it on/off with your foot. Nice if you want to go to the toilet at night without turning the whole light on to wake up.
- comfy blankets and pillows. Pillows for bed/sofa, blanket on a chair.
- Your can get some rope hangers for plant pots for a good price if you like hanging plants.
- organizers keep clutter out of the way. I particularly like drawers that go in the PCs CD bay
- there's some pretty neat organizers for saving space in the closet for clothes
- cable organizers for clutter
- If you like the aesthetic there's sheet metal posters you can put on walls. Pictures are usually not worth it, posters may be if you like them.
- other than that it depends on your style. If you like the "hoarding weeb" aesthetic, get shelves to display figurines. If you want it more feminine, a lot of whites, pelts, lights (fairly lights are good), and wall art with fake motivational texts. Personally I quite like the "french country home" aesthetic for my kitchen (a lot of wood, metal and rustic things, generally a very open kitchen instead of clean cabinets) and a more industrial sleeping room. Both of those profit from locally buying second hand rather than AliExpress though.

>>90891786
>The room I have it in gets very dusty because I've a projector which does nothing but blow hot air for hours at a time
All the projector does it take dust that's already there and blow it around. And that purifier will work slowly (if at all), not nearly enough to fix a serious dust problem likely. Instead try regular cleaning of the room and ventilation. If you then still want to filter it out, get a normal filter with a fan blowing the air through it. The filter will need replacement, but in return it will actually filter enough to make a measurable difference.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The colon operator is not simply a replacement for a division symbol. : is a ratio, everything on either side of it has to be resolved before it. Then you can resolve it as if it was a division symbol.
It helps to think of the colon as A:B=(A)/(B), or A*B:C*D=(A*B)/(C*D).
(36:3(8-6))/6
(36:3(2))/6
(36:6)/6=(36/6)/6
6/6=1
It's a stupid way to write this equation, created specifically to confuse people and start arguments.

posts.com:
This comes down to whether you view x(y) to mean that the contents of y are modified by x or to mean x*(y). It IS actually different. I think that in algebra, most people would use x as a modifier for the contents of y, even the people who are saying the answer is 4.

For example:

Simplify 3y÷3x. Almost nobody would say that it simplifies to y÷x, because that's wrong, but that's effectively what you're doing when you say the OP expression simplifies to 4.

BEDMAS/PEMDAS/whatever is a very dumbed down version of how mathematical rules work. If you were strict about it, you couldn't evaluate the expression (x-y)^2 because you can't simplify x-y. If brackets/parenthesis are always first, how can I write that (x-y)^2=x^2+y^2-2xy? It's because BEDMAS/PEMDAS/whatever is for brainlets who don't actually know math. It's a simplification of the actual rules of math. Nobody doing high level math has to remind themselves of the order in which things should be done and often do things that would be considered illegal under the doctrine of BEDMAS/PEMDAS/whatever.

posts.com:
Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other W10 editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice/WPS and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90912578
That's different than what you asked previously, since you made it very clear that the BIOS didn't give you any output whatsoever.

>I'm basically asking: if the BIOS works properly will it give an error if it detects an OS that isn't compatible with the motherboard
Only if it does so before executing the code. BIOSs can perform certain sanity checks, but most of the time it won't know that the OS can boot until it attempts to boot (also see "halting problem"). Once the CPU starts executing code that comes from a drive the BIOS is virtually out of the equation (except for management engine bullshit and the sort).

Can you explain what your 2 batch scripts do?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90917396
The first one executes where on the first argument passed to the command. So if you do whedit whedit, it will open notepad to edit whedit.bat. whedit ssh will open notepad for ssh.exe, you don't really want to edit that it'll break. Only works for things that where actually picks up, so they must be executable files in your PATH. The Unix equivalent would just be notepad $(which $1) but it's very difficult to use that style even in PowerShell which supports subshells. Fortunately cmd for loops are powerful as shit and we can use literally anything as a token.
The second one just treekills every program that matches the name you put. I've been using it for FESearchHost but it can also save you from fork bombs or such. Unfortunately while cmd does have a dedicated macro called %errorlevel% to store the errorlevel of the most recent invoked program, we can't really use it in an if statement to branch here even with delayedexpansion enabled since taskkill just doesn't set it properly for some reason I couldn't tell you. It's not the only binary in System32 that acts like that despite returning integer error codes like you'd expect. But && and || builtins use a lower-level API to get the success status so the ugly goto-if-failed style works. It's a Tron: Legacy reference, obviously.

Just make a secondary user account for each app like this, and then forced UAC prompts with runas in your script. Each secondary user has access ONLY to the directory the application is in and to any other data directories you wish to give it.

Now, ffmpeg or any other app can be run more securely in that malicious changes are somewhat sandboxed without incurring any performance hits. An alternative, though maybe overkill, is to use docker for a lot of this stuff.

I wish there was an OS that could assign permissions on a per app not per user basis, but alas. Something like simplewall but for the filesystem.

posts.com:
>>90919807
"in situ" means "in place"
>>90918446
>Is there a way to elevate a CMD/Powershell process in situ?
No, due to how Windows privileges work it's only possible to create a new process with an elevated security token. It is by design.
>Is there a script or pattern to use to capture all registry changes/settings changes during an installation
It can be done, but it's not easy. For one way migration you can simply move the hard drive to a new machine. Windows after 8.1 is able to more or less recover even from huge hardware changes. It might take a few reboots but it should get there.
A proper way of doing a migration like this is to generalize your Windows image using sysprep. This will transform it into a state close to what the first reboot after installing Windows is, but with your programs/data intact.
>and then sync those between devices?
That is way harder. If you want to have the same stuff between different installations you need a central management system to deploy everything. It is probably impossible to fully sync manually installed programs because of how Windows is constructed.
There are half-solutions like making a system snapshot, installing your software, making another snapshot and creating a .MSI of the difference, but it's error-prone.

Use good cross-platform utilities such as bat, ripgrep, sd, jq, neovim/micro, 7zip and lf.
Get GNU utils from Chocolatey if you still need them.
Get the latest powershell core (pwsh.exe, not powershell.exe)

Use Windows Terminal and remember you can open the needed folder right from Explorer window.

One pain point I still have is that a lot of tools (say, Python subprocess library) assumes cmd as the shell. You can do 'pwsh.exe -c', but will it handle quoting, piping, escaping, ect. correctly?

function concpal(s) {
    const stk = [];
    for (let c of s) {
        if (stk.length > 0 && stk.at(-1) === c) {
            stk.pop();
        } else {
            stk.push(c);
        }
    }

    return stk.length === 0;
}

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90925838
For every possible cut point k in the string we need to figure out if s[:k] and s[k:] are palindromes. We can do it by using rolling string hashes (computing s[0]+s[1]*x+s[2]*x^2 + ... and reverse s[0]*x^(k-1)+s[1]*x^(k-2)+...): for palindromes the two hashes will be the same. You can also see that they can be incrementally updated.
Let's do hashing modulo a log n bit prime. We get a collision with probability ~1/n in which case we just re-check naively (but because it happens so rarely we end up being constant expected time). We get a log factor because operating with O(k) bit primes takes ~k log k but in practice you can just pick p=2^61-1 and that'll fit in a word size so nbd.

>>90899473
Just watch what you're doing when using pacman and actually read PKGBUILDs if you're installing stuff from the AUR and you should be ok. Do not update literally every minute like some morons tell you to. Update weekly and if you're going to install a new package and haven't done so in a while.

Do NOT check for updates by running "pacman -Syu" and canceling. This can fuck you up. Install pacman-contrib and run "checkupdates" instead.

If you're using Yay, I think it allows you to inspect PKGBUILDs by default. "yay -Pw" also is pretty handy to run before updates because if something requires manual intervention, it'll be posted on the front page of the arch website. If you don't want to use yay, subscribe to the rss feed or the mailing list.

>>90914207
>How do binary package managers work?
It's different per package management system.
RPMs aren't made like DEBs for example.
But that's determined by the maintainer of the repos, being Debian and RHEL.
Now if you go with Arch and install from the AUR, know that it's a user repo and that anyone can upload anything and it's up to you to be smart.
>Do they not provide source at all?
No.
>Who audits the binaries?
That depends on whether it's a user repo or an official repo.
>What's the process of making a binary for one?
See answer 1.

posts.com:
>>90920549
See https://ffmpeg.org/ffmpeg-filters.html#Notes-on-filtergraph-escaping
For the specific purpose of ffmpeg filtergraph escaping, your simplest option is to enclose the string in ' ' and replace every ' in file names with '\''
-filter_complex "subtitles='$(printf '%s' "$f" | sed -E "s/'/'\\\'')':si=1"

Another one that works for pretty much anything with \ escapes is 
sed -E 's/(.)/\\\1/'
which just puts a \ in front of every character. This doesn't work for ffmpeg 2nd level statements though.

>>90920583
Doesn't work in general because : is a ffmpeg special character.

;; a comment macro for elisp (like clojure)
;; >>87116763
;; https://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/comment
(defmacro comment (&rest body) nil)

;; https://www.emacswiki.org/emacs/ThreadMacroFromClojure
(defmacro -> (&rest body)
  (let ((result (pop body)))
    (dolist (form body result)
      (setq result (append (list (car form) result)
                           (cdr form))))))

(defmacro ->> (&rest body)
  (let ((result (pop body)))
    (dolist (form body result)
      (setq result (append form (list result))))))

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90905561
Yeah, so the idea is to reimplement a modern web browser from the ground up in a single extensible layer using lisp. Obviously you're sol if you want to use the normal stack(though it MAY be possible to do some wizardry, I'm not hopeful for a magical open source html rendering engine anytime soon), so instead you use something else, probably sexps, maybe byte compile and compressed. Now you've basically reinvented HTML+CSS+JS. Did you do a better job? Maybe. And then you've got to network all this, and it's obviously going to have to be p2p since lets face it, it'll never be popular enough for a server ecosystem to make sense. Best way to do that is a DHT, maybe a skipgraph, you've now reinvented DNS, but much slower and more complicated since it needs to run on normal machines and not optically accelerated ASICs.
Lets say you finish it, you've got your perfect networked searchable all lisp ecosystem you can hook into from any computer anywhere in the world. How do you run programs not written in lisp? Now you've got to make untold amounts of libraries, hooks, boilerplate, etc... all in multiple other languages across lots of architectures just to attempt running the stuff.

Meanwhile, WASM already runs in browsers, it's based on sexps, operates off the normal internet, runs on all platforms, and works as a compilation target for all existing languages so old software can be directly compiled into WASM and run both in the browser and directly on bare metal. All the work has already been done, you can go try it out right now.

Obviously the answer is to take WASM and use it to build your lisp ecosystem idea, but currently it doesn't have GC or memory management, so everyone's stuck in limbo waiting for the ability for the ability of modules to create and execute other modules. Once that gets going it's just a matter of implementing a simple framework and you've got a single page operating system.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90907912
Not platform interop, PROGRAM interop. If OTHER programs can also be compiled into wasm you can use the wasm interface to do cross machine IPC. Basically, because it all runs on the same virtual machine, you can ship the memory state around and reuse it without doing any translation, just like CL images. So you can run autocad in wasm on your machine, then pause the system, zip the vm state, send it to another computer, and continue from where you left off.
Or, if you implement an entire os in wasm, you could hibernate your entire system into a file, and using those augmented hyperlinks I mentioned before, remotely back it up, open and run it, dissassemble and step through it, etc...
The reason you want to actually use wasm instead of just compiling to it or compiling to x86 is in order to use these high level features your program has to KNOW it's running in wasm and how wasm modules/memories work and how to run them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90907979
Really that's just showing the superiority of interpreters and the tyranny of compiled assembly. If I'm running 15 layered javascript operating systems and using 15 GB of memory and 1kw of power to run a webshit calculator, the performance gains of compilers are moot. Who fucking cares if it takes 1000 times as long to crunch numbers if my computer is 10,000,000 times faster?
Sure, don't try to do graphics with an interpreter, BUT THE CPU DOESN'T DO THAT ANYWAY! The commands get COMPILED TO SHADER CODE! So all the graphics and numbercrunching shit can just be compiled for the GPU, and all general purpose CPU bound code can be interpreted!
Boom, 90% of all programs are now irrelevant and obsolete!
>don't need compilers
>don't need process control since you can cram entire vm images into continuations
>don't need multithreading libraries, just run one interpreter per core, all the images are single threaded
>don't need containerization, ALL PROCESSES are containers
>don't need access control, if you've got the link for data you have access, if you don't you can't reach it since it doesn't even exist as far as you're concerned
>don't need a browser, all your os level programs are trivially networked and distributed, you can replace a website with a program image and automatically download it, run it in a sandboxed container, and have it access server side data itself
>don't need suspend, hibernate, shutdown, restart, etc... since your entire system state is just a file

>>90908183
>better building blocks than purely manipulating strings on buffers?
terrible idea. everything being strings in buffers is like the best part of emacs. i think a better way to get more structured interpretations of the buffer is to implement internal mechanisms that allow you to collapse parts of the buffer. e.g. say you want to apply org-mode to all comments in the buffer. you should be able to collapse all the code sections so that when org-mode runs it appears as though its in a buffer of plain org-mode text. efficiently doing so is probably a difficult problem. you could rip out the text you want and put it in another buffer then transplant it back but thats probably slow.

i don't think this is exactly the kind of structure the mage guy has in mind though. he doesn't want structured reinterpretations of a buffer, he wants text to not be ascii streams at all and to stuff it in terrible tree representations and possibly other structures for muh notes. i want to be able to reuse text editing code in buffers where said text i want to run that code on is mixed with other content and contains other syntax and line prefixes i want to ignore. the fact that org-mode already parses buffers into trees is one of its biggest flaws.

>>90913361
>but why?
I'm using this to save various window configurations.
https://emacs.stackexchange.com/a/73858/37580

That w/load function works fine as long as the buffers referenced by the window configurations exists. Here's what a window configuration might look like:
      '(((min-height . 4)
         (min-width . 10)
         (min-height-ignore . 4)
         (min-width-ignore . 6)
         (min-height-safe . 1)
         (min-width-safe . 2)
         (min-pixel-height . 48)
         (min-pixel-width . 50)
         (min-pixel-height-ignore . 48)
         (min-pixel-width-ignore . 30)
         (min-pixel-height-safe . 12)
         (min-pixel-width-safe . 10))
        leaf
        (pixel-width . 1366)
        (pixel-height . 687)
        (total-width . 273)
        (total-height . 57)
        (normal-height . 1.0)
        (normal-width . 1.0)
        (buffer "queries.sql"
                (selected . t)
                (hscroll . 0)
                (fringes 8 8 nil nil)
                (margins nil)
                (scroll-bars nil 0 t nil 0 t nil)
                (vscroll . 0)
                (dedicated)
                (point . 211)
                (start . 1))
        (prev-buffers
         ("res.md" 1 1)
         ("res.json" 1 377)))


If there is no buffer for "queries.sql", w/load won't do anything. However, if the buffer already exists, then it'll setup the frame as described by the above data structure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90915259
Yup, CL has SET. The advantage that SET has compared to SETF or SETQ is that SET is a real function: the first argument is evaluated, just like any other, and it has to produce a symbol, which can be obtained by evaluating any arbitrary subexpression. In fact, the target of the assignment can thus be determined dynamically.

Now, in practice, everyone uses SETF 99.99% of the time in CL, which is the correct thing to do. But having a function like SET can be useful for some edge cases.

>>90915259

>
(set! (if (my-pred?) 'foo 'bar) "some value")

hmmm
what if you made a macro to do that? something like this, but in scheme. i can't into hygienic scheme macros so here is what i came up with in CL:
(defun wrap-clause (clause)
  (destructuring-bind (pred sym val) clause
    `(if ,pred (setf ,sym ,val))))

(defun nest-clauses (clauses)
  (reduce (lambda (c acc) (append c (list acc)))
          clauses :from-end t))

(defmacro cond-setf (val-form &body clauses)
  (let ((val (gensym)))
    `(let ((,val ,val-form))
       ,(nest-clauses
         (mapcar (lambda (c) (wrap-clause (append c `(,val))))
                 clauses)))))

it works like this
(cond-setf "some value"
  ((pred-1?) foo)
  ((pred-2?) bar)
  (t         baz))

turns into
(LET ((#:G366 "some value"))
  (IF (PRED-1?)
      (SETF FOO #:G366)
      (IF (PRED-2?)
          (SETF BAR #:G366)
          (IF T
              (SETF BAZ #:G366)))))

>>90913829
It's metal shell, which feels and looks nice, but isn't always to best in-ear comfort compared to higher-end resin. For example, cold weather, it will feel ice cold when you first put em in. Also, physical properties potentially lead to more moisture ingress and condensation.
If you check out SeeAudio's Facebook page, they send out a letter regarding Yume II unit failures. They do address it directly and extend their warranty & replacement services, which is actually a good sign about the character of their company. Side anecdote: I do have a SeeAudio product (Bravery Anniversary Edition) and when I communicated via Aliexpress with Angelears Audio Store, they were very prompt in communication (not regarding any kind of replacement need, but for an extra promo discount I won, and did receive promptly).
In all, nothing of major concern in my opinion considering the world of ChiFi. Many worse ways and worse companies to get screwed by. Worst case your unit fails, as long as you get it through a trusted Aliexpress store, you should be covered or via communication with SeeAudio directly. Best case, it's a well-tuned IEM that we can hope improves upon OG Yume which was generally well-regarded for it's tonality and tuning. (Take note of Crin's older collabs, he hand picked models that were already good (for their time) ie FH3 -> FHE, Yume -> Yume Midnight, etc) It slots into a segment above sub-$100 1DDs, yet below 1DD+4BA hybrids of higher price points.

>>90915002
The price is always going to go up because if you talk to people in this autisic hobby they'll always tell you "well if you spend 20 more dollars you can get this and that", the truth is diminishing returns are a very real thing and past a certain point (pretty early on) the difference is really minuscule if it exists at all.
If you watch people blind testing IEMs or headphones at different price points (like, 50 dollar ones going up against 500 dollar ones), they can still get it wrong even if they're very experienced with the hobby. You just have to ground yourself and set a limit instead of chasing the perfect IEM which does not exist, pick something that you think would fit and you think you would like, something that looks nice if that matters to you, something with a sound you think or know you'll like that isn't complete dogshit and just enjoy it.

I like them for sound, as they offer a very wide bore, but I don't always love their comfort with some IEMs. Spring Tips can be a bit too flimsy at times, so as I find good alternatives they'll probably get swapped out.

>>90915208
This anon speaks truth... can only ever listen to one (1) IEM at a time bros. It is fine if you have surplus income and consciously decide "This is a collector hobby I want to get into," "I'm interested in the different driver technology and sounds IEMs can produce" But do not fall into trap of repetitive pos purchases and hype trains. Start near budget and if something sounds good, there is no "need to upgrade." Hit play and enjoy. More expensive BA hybrids this-and-that just offer different flavors of sound, different timbre, etc. Tuning and frequency response = >80% the experience, and FR of cheap pos gets better every week. Mythological concept of "technicalities" set by kilobuck shit like Anole VX is autism. Car analogy: kilobuck is Lamborghini or w/e. Such overkill for purpose of "drive from A-to-B." $20 budget are perfectly good Honda Civics. Drive well and reliably. Choose whatever in-between step/level you want to go to, but understand the diminishing returns and excess spending that occurs at the higher levels

We've had 500Hz for almost a year now.
https://rog.asus.com/articles/news/the-rog-swift-500hz-shatters-boundaries-with-its-ultra-fast-panel/
What he probably means is the absolute pixel reaction time, in which CRT have a distinct advantage by not being sample-and-hold like LCD.
Even a 60Hz CRT will have superior motion clarity to a LCD. However the latter can emulate it with BFI (black frame insertion), which strobes the back light. The downside is limited brightness and having the controller be very complex - only ASUS has a proper implementation that actually works together with VRR and doesn't produce too many artifacts.

>I have the Viewsonic XG2431 and the backlight strobing is crazy. Up the pixel clock rate of 60hz in the EDID and you have motion clarity on par with a CRT. I think it works up to 100hz too.
That looks like a nice monitor, but it's FHD so doesn't fit my requirements. Hacking EDID sounds like a dangerous thing for the longevity of the panel itself tho.
>But how did ASUS get it working with VRR?
Good question, but they are not the first to have it working. Early generations of BFI were limited to 120Hz, but my 1440p "IPS" (AHVA gen2) ASUS can do it over the full range up to 170Hz.
Being FreeSync/G-SYNC Compatible probably helps because it unshackles you from the NOVIDEO module's limitations. I haven't tested a G-SYNC ULTIMATE yet, but G-SYNC gen1 and gen2 had only fixed refresh BFI.
>With the way that backlight strobing works, it seems like it would be impossible to dynamically change the refresh rate while doing it.
Mine has few zones of backlight so I guess it can be dynamically adjusted with a rolling mode. I do not have a camera fast enough to capture this, sadly.

>>90914218
you can take a look at the tests made by RTINGs as they actually measure off axis color washout and contrast and such.

In my experience (70 inch Samsung VA television) the off-axis (around 30+ degrees) contrast level is around the same of a good quality IPS, somewhere in the neighborhood of 1200:1 to 1500:1. It is a decent difference from the center of the picture but it is only really noticeable in very dark scenes, at which point I find better to enable the autobrightness function and allow it to dim the screen slightly which mitigates most of the effect, at least when watching in dark environments

#include <iostream>

int numberTwice(int x)
{
    return x * 2;
}

int askQuestion()
{
    std::cout << "Please enter an integer: ";
    int userAnswer{};
    std::cin >> userAnswer;
    std::cin.get();

    return userAnswer;
}

int main()
{
    int num{ askQuestion() };
    int numTwo{ numberTwice(num)};

    std::cout << "You chose: " << num << "." << '\n';
    std::cout << num << " doubled is: " << numTwo << "." << '/n';
    std::cin.get();

    return 0;
}



Why does this result in a decimal?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

std::cout << num << " doubled is: " << numTwo << "." << '/n';

>>90910237
If you can onlock Bitlocker then sure, it works like on any other storage. For this you simply boot from the disk while it's in the original computer, or use another Linux computer / Live CD and unlock the encrypted partition using the Bitlocker recovery key.
If you're not an administrator on that Windows installation or don't know the recovery key then no, photorec won't be able to recover anything – this is the whole point of encrypting in the first place.

>>90918456
Because phone SOCs are intended for disposable devices that you throw away after a few years.
Qualcomm supports its SOCs for three years and the end of support means the end of your device, since even critical vulnerabilities won't be fixed. Samsung is the same shit, although they promised that they'll do better at some point in the future.
You must design your own ARM CPU if you want to release a device that comes close to a PC in terms of longevity, buying a SOC just doesn't work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90925576
Yes pretty much. That's also why there is a dozen distros even though they all use the same applications in the end. Generally you should also have a package manager - but technically, if you don't have one, you could still call it a distro.

>Linus Torvalds developed the Linux kernel and distributed its first version, 0.01, in 1991. Linux was initially distributed as source code only, and later as a pair of downloadable floppy disk images: one bootable and containing the Linux kernel itself, and the other with a set of GNU utilities and tools for setting up a file system. Since the installation procedure was complicated, especially in the face of growing amounts of available software, distributions sprang up to simplify it.[13]

>Early distributions included:
> H. J. Lu's "Boot-root", the aforementioned disk image pair with the kernel and the absolute minimal tools to get started (late 1991)[14]
> MCC Interim Linux (February 1992)
> Softlanding Linux System (SLS) which included the X Window System and was the most comprehensive distribution for a short time (1992)
> Yggdrasil Linux/GNU/X, a commercial distribution (December 1992)
>From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linux_distribution

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90926350
Because the source material was different.
Not all audio is the same – small and barely audible differences like bit depth, sampling rate, and low-pass filtering can significantly affect file size.
If you convert an FLAC to MP3 and back to FLAC, the resulting file will be significantly smaller than the initial one because some data was discarded in the process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Ok here's my take.
What the shell needs to do is start processes, and you need to manage those.
Everything related to processed happens concurrently and asynchronously by nature, starting/stopping a process, signals, IPC, and the shell needs to have all the primitives to control them.

Although the shell's name is a pun and was intented to make us thing about the synergy shell/kernel and hints at the system call interface, the shell doesn't need to being able to make all system calls, it just needs to be able to start/stop processes, send send signals, make them communicate, filesystem operations (cd, ls, pwd, stat, chmod, chown, etc..) that's it. Making use of all the other system calls is the role of a real programming language, wether "system"/compiled or scripting language.

Often you do not lauch processes to have side effects but to obtain data from them, and you want to be able to process that data.
Making 2 "real programs" communicate is something that should be easy to do,
BUT,
making the data processing happen with fork/exec/wait/pipe and using separate executables to do trivial things like string filtering (grep), is really fucking stupid. There is absolutely no reason to do it this way. It's inefficient and it's not even good.
1/

>>90900448
The shell should have all the usual operations that you'd have in a scripting language builting (simple variables, arrays, hash tables, number and string operations, regexes (one embeded regex engine for all regex operations just like perl and scripting langauges do), list operations (filter/grep, map, sort, uniq, etc..), and also control flow (good this time). Also, it should be easy to compose everything and not have stupid quotation and wordsplitting rules in your way.

If you don't have that you end up using perl just like I do.
Basically I'm arguing for a scripting langage with a lightweight syntax adapted to launch little commands.

I am convinced that it should have been like that if in an impossible reality we had scripting languages before shells, because clearly Ken Thomspon and Bourne couldn't into functional-like/expressive languages.
I've got the impression that it's what PowerShell is about anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90903031
if grep, sed, awk, etc or something equivalent was buitltin, the entire stream could be optimized away, like no need to pass 1 line into 3 pipes and process consecutively, but instead have ony 1 loop representing the entire stream
grep something becomes
if ( ! match(line, somehting)) {
    continue;
}

sed s/pat/text/g becomes
substitute(&line, "pat", "text", "g");

each of those conditionals are one after the other inside the body of the loop
if you do this, it would be extremely cache friendly and would proabbly be an order of magnitude faster if not more

Machine language in .ELF files -> kernel processes -> scripting language interpreter (or java, the fanciest of scripting languages) -> app platform -> your app

Machine language in .ELF files -> kernel processes -> your app linked to libraries installed in other files

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90908540
Arch defines simplicity as without unnecessary additions or modifications. Packages are only split when compelling advantages exist, so most packages are bigger and come with all features enabled. It also makes it harder to control what you want on your system (e.g. changing init system or replacing udev with mdev), but makes it easier to follow upstream closely. Arch is KISS for the maintainers and UpToDate for the users.

posts.com:
>>90916951
Because concatenating strings, if you do not do so in a specific way is actually an O(N^2) operation (might not be O(N^2), but it's pretty bad)
See the stringbuilder class in java
Adding strings to eachother repeatedly forces the interpreter to create a new string, so say you have
"Jimmy","Tim","Thomas"
"Jimmy"
"Jimmy" + "Tim" -> "JimmyTim"
"JimmyTim" + "Thomas" -> "JimmyTimThomas"
You see how that gets bad for space complexity and also time complexity allocating new space and filling it? Now imagine we're doing that with like 50 strings in a for loop, it gets pretty shitty

The install / swap is bog standard shit so nothing to add, if you know how to solder it's the easiest 4 solder joints of your life (I don't know how to solder so it's 20 minutes of wondering if I'm doing it right to realize that i'm likely not but it works so whatever, and my solder joint held after a 3ft fall so i'm doing something right)

The sound post swap is the fucking best thing i've ever heard out of $80 of gear, big but not overbearing bass with a small mid bass hump but unlike the stock driver here it goes all the way down to sub bass, it also feels way wider sounding than stock

10/10 gud mod, needs comfier pads

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90919806
>>90924645
>What is the state of the art in headphone form factor transducers
There is a lot of marketing fluff surrounding this but most if not the entirety of sound quality can be described by frequency response at the ear drum and distortion, which of course originate from transducers but for someone just looking to get new headphones the differences in driver technology are just not that impactful. Dynamic drivers are fine, arguably better than planar magnetic and electrostatic in the sense that they're generally cheap, reliable, lightweight, easy to drive, and can still have a frequency range that extends past human hearing. Planar magnetic tend to have lower distortion so they're a bit better when it comes to open-backs that will be EQed to fix roll-off or add a bass shelf, they look cool too.
> what are their most neutral consumer implementations?
If you mean neutral sound, the term as lost most of its meaning. The HD 800s for example has a flat bass response and is fairly bright, to me that isn't neutral and true neutrality is what represents music as it sounds in real life which to my ears would be more bass, more energy in the 1-4 kHz range, and slightly less treble, that would create a frequency response similar to what has validated by preference research over the last decade, referred to as the Harman target. More into the weeds but there there is also the question of if you should even want a neutral sound because a lot of music is flat and lacking detail. An aggressive V-shape done right in my view is unrated and very good for movies and games since the stimulus isn't as constant and listener fatigue is less of a factor.

Not sure if any of this answers your question but there's no hard-and-fast rule that equates to buy X headphones if you like classical and opera music.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90914242
Your mentality is in the right place, but what zoomers fail to understand is that some dumb phones used to market themselves as doubling as MP3 players, and some of them were pretty good. 15+ years ago it was not all that uncommon to have a device which was basically a pretty good mp3 player that had physical buttons and could make calls. Almost none of these devices had a touch screen. They had an older style of texting where you had to hit a number key a certain amount of times to get a letter.

The comfiest of all phones is a dumb phone with a headphone jack, no touch screen, and expandable storage like a micro-sd card.

We need to bring that form factor back. I am hoping to pull off something similar to how those phones were with the Maid Phone.

What else do retro hobbyist zoomers want their phone to do? There might be more ideas from zoomers who like retro tech that can go in it.

So far the plan is to put a compiler, a means of voice call, a text chatting application, an mp3 player, an ad hoc Bluetooth network of some kind (maybe, I want this so people can wirelessly share mp3s with people who are close by) and all the server software needed to have your own phone exchange because it doesn't matter how secure the client is, if you don't control the server.

Thank you dra/g/ons for reading my post.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90914492
They didn’t kill minidisc like that, minidisc was relatively popular outside the US. In the US our record labels basically murdered it because of how easy it was to copy and transfer digital music.
Sony even tried to entice them with Monetization options where you’d be able to plug minidiscs into kiosks and buy individual tracks to put on them, but only a few labels in the US would put out music on MD under the concern of piracy.

But that was only part of the death of MD, it was mainly that shortly after MD’s start of relevancy there came proper digital storage players, portable Jukeboxes, early mp3 players, and then the iPods concept which completely killed any interest in physical media players as anything other than a cheaper alternative, and CD Walkman models were cheaper than MD anyway, and people already owned a lot of CDs. So people just stuck with CD and skipped MD until digital downloaded music took over entirely.

posts.name: ed666
posts.sub: Glacies - A sane and small linux/OS
posts.com:
A sane linux/OS in the building:
own non-posix libc (safe system library)
own coreutils
own posix libc, actually a compat layer (simia)
musl-based (may merge with simia)
s6 init
functional package manager
reproducible "redo"(djb) build system
scripts in execline
mksh as sh
(follow in the details the package in the arbor repo)

Its next step is to add arcan (already done in private, just finishing details), and soon a GUI installer.

Read more about and in bigger details at: https://eltaninos.org

If you wanna join the community for now prefer the matrix room, the IRC future is unsure (I may change the server or at least confirm ownership of the current one)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90925845
He is a dumbass, this doesn't apply to passwords in any sane system.

You can only reasonably bruteforce if you have the hashed password or the think you want to decipher locally.
Password are not stored directly in the database, they are hashed.
Hashing is destructive by nature, there is no way to "unhash" meangin that when you want to check for a password, you hash it and compare to the hash you have stored.
Bruteforcing in that case means you first acquire the stored hash then hash all possible password until you find one that matches, it might not be the "real" password but works the same (the probability it is the "real" one is extremely high though).

You technically can try every possibility via the website/software but yeah, good system will answer too slow and block the account to prevent that.

what this guy here >>90925826 is talking about is probably WPA2 cracking which does not apply to your normal webservices, it's a different thing. You can capture the handshake of another device connecting to an access point, store the handshake locally and then try cracking it. Kind of impossible though if the access points default password hasn't been changed to "password" because they're usually pretty safe.

posts.com:
ITT: we explore cheaper and less disasterous alternatives to Yubikeys and FIDO2-based authenticators

Depending on your threat model, you may be able to get away with much more convenient forms of security in the form of a physical key.

Instead of storing your GPG and SSH keys on a shitty TPM device that can and will fail, locking you out of everything, why not just use secure randomized passphrases for your GPG and SSH keys that you can store as a QR code, or as the data payload section of an NFC tag?
These can work both on your phone or on your desktop, and aren't subject to hardware failure.
The QR code has the added benefit of not requiring any special hardware.

Before you go and call this retarded, this offers the same level of security as a TOTP device, except you don't need a shitty $50 dongle to do it.

>>90922912
not a precise definition but they arise naturally as the categorification of closure operators; which is a much simpler and probably more familiar concept, especially because closure operators (specifically on power sets) are a common occurrence in topology, algebra, set theory, logic, ...
preorders are essentially thin (and usually small) categories
viewed this way, monotone functions between preorders become functors between the categories, galois connections become adjunctions and closure operators become monads (and kernel operators become comonads)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90912060
Routers delay the packages sent by a random amount of time.

In each layer of the onion, there is a random amount of padding. Pair that with compression, and you got a package that varies in size each hop.

Tor nodes create and repeat randomly generated traffic, indistinguishable from real traffic, which bounces around the network. Not even the nodes themselves know if its real traffic or not.


In other words: You cannot utilize timed attacks anymore. And you couldn't for a long time now.

>>90907396
>ever heard of time correlation attacks?
Requires the attacher to own a substantial portion of the network, and it's extremely resource intensive (therefore the glowies have to target you specifically), and it's confounded by switching circuits often, and it's never been demonstrated to ever have been used in the wild.

The Tor protocol isn't perfect, but it's very nearly so, near enough that trust in its implementation beats out any distrust in the protocol.

posts.com:
>>90925668
you can do that with a laptop, it only requires a wifi adapter whose hardware and driver supports being put into monitor mode, basically a mode where it just sits on a channel and listens to all traffic, without actually taking part (connecting to) the network
wifi is a shared medium, you see, when everyone is connected to a network on a particular channel, there's only that one channel to use, imagine 10 people using walkie-talkies set to the same channel, they all have to take turns, the same goes for wifi
this is why you can capture everyones' wifi traffic, because they're all on the same channel only "speaking" one at a time

posts.com:
Been tinkering around with alacritty and tmux lately.
I've been trying to minimize hidden directories in home lately. As part of that, I moved ~/.config to ~/Library/Preferences and discovered that alacritty apparently hardcodes ~/.config if you're not on a system that uses XDG.
I edited and recompiled alacritty in order for it to use ~/Library/Preferences and read the correct config file on launch.
While this solution works, it seems that alacritty should read /etc/profile or /etc/bashrc, see that I've set XDG_CONFIG_HOME and use that value, but it doesn't.
I don't know rust at all, but it seems that alacritty uses some xdg package to determine which directory to use, and as macOS doesn't use it, it just defaults to ~/.config, rather than reading env vars.
Thanks for reading my blog, sometimes I wish I didn't have this kind of autism

A while back I decided to just set XDG vars because some of my applications use their existence to determine where cache, config, etc, files should be placed. I read a few SO posts that made suggestions as to where the mac equivalent should be and set picrel as part of my dotfiles.
>Supports XDG
I don't think that lib supports macOS tho, not in the way I want it to, anyhow. I edited the file you linked so that it reads
let fallback = PathBuf::from(&home).join("Library/Preferences/alacritty/alacritty.yml");

and it worked. I don't care enough to dig into the xdg lib being used to make it work "correctly", good enough I guess. Oddly enough, compiling the newer version of alacritty fixed a bug that was preventing me from copying text when using tmux.
As far as hidden files in home, I only have .ssh, .Trash and .bash_profile left. The SSH directory can be moved, just have to edit /etc/ssh/ssh_config and sshd_config to point to ~/Library/Preferences/ssh or wherever, but I haven't figured out which option I need to set so that ssh finds the correct config file.

I just figured out how to use ocamlformat
let rec print_char c n =
  match n with
  | 0 -> ()
  | _ ->
      print_string c;
      print_char c (n - 1)

let print_line height index char =
  print_char " " (height - index + 2);
  print_char char ((2 * index) + 1);
  print_char " " (height - index);
  print_string "
"

let print_tree height =
  for i = 0 to height do
    print_line height i "*"
  done;
  print_line height 1 "|"

let tree_height = 18

let () =
  print_string "

";
  print_tree tree_height

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90921403
>Name a better programming language syntax
In no particular order:
Lisp, Python, Rust, and Haskell (OCaml if it wasn't ugly).
>annotating some random fact about a function is good because I said so
I have never once had to check weather a function is recursive or not.
Conclusion: writing it at the top of a function is a waste of time.
Even if you actually did care about this, you could just do it in a comment above the function (but no one will because it's useless information).

>>90921687
>special feature that check an hint for the parens level
Almost every code editor in existence will highlight matching parens and that's all you really need.
There's some fancy stuff like colouring matching parens, but that is mostly useful for making expressions on the same line stand out, which is useful in any language.
>Stockholm syndrome
I would argue that this is a positive.
Of the languages I listed, I've used lisp the least, and I started learning it after the rest.
I think Rust is pretty ugly at times, yet since I've been using it more than lisp I should have developed an attachment to it and find it better.
The fact that only lisp becomes beautiful once you use it for a while is a point in its favour.
Lisp has a higher skill floor and skill ceiling.
It's harder to use for a beginner, but an advanced user will be much better off.
The same goes for editor features; lisp in combination with a lisp editor (or even just vim) is easier to edit than all other languages.
I would rather have the best experience by installing an editor that gives me it than suffer an inferior one because I need to support the people who don't want to install a good editor.

>Oh yeah I really love for analyzer to go batshit crazy when I refactor because there is now extra ) somewhere
I've never had this issue before because:

Refactoring and editing are different things.
A complicated refactor may consist of only simple edits.
In fact, a simple refactor is more likely to cause complex edits.

>In December 1978, eighteen of the local farmers, led by Yen Jingchang,[5] met in the largest house in the village. They agreed to break the law at the time by signing a secret agreement to divide the land, a local People's Commune, into family plots. Each plot was to be worked by an individual family who would turn over some of what they grew to the government and the collective whilst at the same time agreeing that they could keep the surplus for themselves. The villagers also agreed that should one of them be caught and sentenced to death that the other villagers would raise their children until they were eighteen years old.[5][6] At the time, the villagers were worried that another famine might strike the village after a particularly bad harvest and more people might die of hunger.[6]

>After this secret capitalist reform, Xiaogang village produced a harvest that was larger than the previous five years combined.[5] Per capita income in the village increase from 22 yuan to 400 yuan with grain output increasing to 90,000 kg in 1979.[6] This attracted significant attention from surrounding villages and before long the government in Beijing had found out. The villagers were fortunate in that at the time China had just changed leadership after Mao Zedong had died. The new leadership under Deng Xiaoping was looking for ways to reform China's economy and the discovery of Xiaogang's innovation was held up as a model to other villages across the country. This led to the abandonment of collectivised farming across China and a large increase in agricultural production. The secret signing of the contract in Xiaogang is widely regarded as the beginning of the period of rapid economic growth and industrialisation that mainland China has experienced in the thirty years since.

>>90919608
I also plan to deliver server software called Maid Exchange. A common problem with "secure" communications is that you have no visibility into the server-side software. A provider may post code somewhere, but you have no guarantee that's what the server you connected to is running and that modifications to steal data or do other evil tasks were not introduced to the copy of the software they are actually running. You end up having to trust centralized servers and anything centralized is easy to subvert with money and nepotism. Meredith Whittaker being in charge of Signal is a prominent example of money and nepotism undermining something people previously considered secure by placing an awful person in the highest leadership position. You also don't know if bad people are using forked clients that have extra tools allowing them to get info from an (intentionally) compromised server.

Running your own CC0 server where none of the code is hidden in 3rd party libraries is a must.

In Kurumi MaidCard, no effort is made to hide the data, because I want people to know the Maid Card has data so they can open it. It's just drawn on top of the Maid Stick (decorative part of the image).

Originally there was no compression with it and every character got it's own 4 by 8 Maid Symbol, but that resulted in File Data Maid Addresses which were too big to be useful. Either exceeding the posting limit or just looking like TV static with no clue what it was supposed to be. So I added Maid-LZW compression so my File Data Maid Address can take less space on the image. Maid-LZW is like LZW except instead of mapping strings and integers together, I used string and Maid Symbols. If you want to read about it more you can see the code inside Kurumi MaidCard and the README has information too.

My goal was to be able to put my code in a 4Chan post so that I don't have to make a dependence on GitHub for distribution. For that to work the Maid Stickers are important because they sort of work like thumbnails and make the code more recognizable at a glance. I am going to fully deprecate GitHub for everyone but corporate users. Requiring personal information to post code must never be normalized.

>>90917087
>By default it completely replaces your DE with a 'minimalist' garbage fire without basic shit like dpi scaling, a desktop, bluetooth and wifi config, or an application menu
Poor wording. A tiling WM doesn't replace anything by default. It's a standalone window manager. You can either run it by itself and implement all of those things, or, alternatively, many DEs allow you to replace the window manager with one of your choice.

>or trying to tard-wrangle a proper DE to work with the new wm
I used Openbox with XFCE for a long time, it worked just fine. Maybe integrating a tiling window manager is a little more awkward, I dunno.

Anyway, I generally agree that having to implement and maintain all of that bullshit yourself is a huge drawback of tiling WMs. I do wish tiling scripts/modes built into full fledged DEs were more common. The PopOS tiling mode works really well, and Bismuth on KDE is alright (although it doesn't see a lot of development and has a lot of bugs). I'm looking forward to the native tiling mode KDE is getting, myself.

This experience taught me everything about human psychology. I'm basically Freud at this point. Whenever I make a thread about this, I get thousands of moralfags screeching self-serving one-liners to me: "actions have consequences!", "women deserve to know the truth about their date!", "Google is so based for exposing you" etc.

Truth, huh? What happened to objectivity, GDPR, and human rights? I can refute each and every one of these arguments, but it doesnt matter. Being right doesnt matter anymore. The Internet has annihilated people's IQ and replaced it with the desire for gossip, virtue signaling, and power over others.
Even people who might have agreed with me in the past about character assassinations being morally wrong, cant resist the thrill of digitally shunning someone from society. Ruining someone online fulfills our inherent desire to kill. We can no longer legally kill, so we turned the Internet into a digital jungle where we can relive the caveman times and simultaneously pretend "it's not real" - except that it is. That's why it feels good. This species sickens me. That's why I don't work and I live off your tax money. It's on you, pal. You greenlit a society that's not worth respecting.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90897665
Permanent ink, really fine lines, lack of bleeding/smearing. Only a sakura micron or something like it can provide these features. They were originally designed for engineers after all. Everything else is just snobbery, you get nothing, you just spend more on a pen. If you have a weak wrist you may notice more comfort and smoothness.

I have 4 fountain pens, mostly gifts, and they are all princesses that produce less legible results on checks (the only thing you NEED pens for) than a sakura micron because the best possible ink still bleeds and spreads out on that thin paper.

I use the pen that is present, or if it is important I fill it out using a sakura micron PN so I can be assured it won't get fucked up and smeared and can't be washed out by some smug fuck with a bottle of acetone.

This dates back to the days when software was distributed on external media. Opening an installer .dmg is like inserting an installer CD. I expect 2 main causes at least:
1. People stick to what they know, since finding something different takes time and effort, what's worse with these sorts of things the way forward is nebulous, so even if you're willing to put time into it the way to find the "right" communication platform is unclear
2. With communication platforms in particular, a large chunk of their value comes from the size of the user base. Lots of people means there's somebody to actually talk to, plus it also means that less common interests have a chance at discussion too since you could find people with said interests in the huge user base. Finding the perfect platform with the perfect design and features is still useless if it's used by 5 people and they post twice a month in total. You wouldn't really be able to go there to talk about something because there's not going to be anyone there to talk to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90882406
This isn't a class component. When using function components there is rarely a need for using "this" and this.state will very likely not be defined.
useState returns an array [currentState, setThisStateFunction].
If you want to access the state use the returned currentState value (in this case named tabActive).
I am a bit confused why you want to access state with this.state.tabActive, you already successfully used it in you if condition, just tabActive.
To set the state to a different value, call setTabActive(newValue)
You should probably read https://beta.reactjs.org/

security bros: i went down an autistic rabbit hole today re: password hashing and came to the conclusion that bcrypt is superior despite its 72-byte truncation, until argon2id becomes the php default and therefore superior (it should have happened in php 7.2-7.3 but internals are pussies)

am i wrong? the prior scheme was using a hardcoded sha512 algo with null byte stripping to enable the use of arbitrary long passwords, which seems good in theory

then i ran some shannon entropy calculators on the outputs and discovered that if your password is 72 bytes of random data (the best possible under bcrypt), string-escaping it reduces the entropy, but so does sha512'ing it

it's also a lot harder/impossible to upgrade the pre-hash algo without forcing a sitewide password reset. ran into that problem trying to upgrade the pre-hash to sha3-512

am i right to believe that bcrypt even with its truncation, and the ability to seamlessly upgrade algos in the future, is better than using an already-outdated hash (sha2) that may be the next md5 re: shucking vulns?

Mobile dev is a lot harder than web/backend for a beginner. Mobile has a lot of quirks and it is a lot harder to get the development environment up and running for mobile.

>>90891503
Mostly it is fine with one server.
But if you want a global system then.

Setup your servers across the globe.
Use Docker Swarm: see this for an easy install https://dockerswarm.rocks/
Add those machines to the same swarm and when you push an update it will automatically update all of the machines.
Or use Kubernetes, but that is more tricky to setup, not that hard nowadays, but harder.

Use Cloudflare or any of the big cloud providers will be able to route traffic based on which server has the lowest ping.
https://developers.cloudflare.com/load-balancing/understand-basics/traffic-steering/steering-policies/proximity-steering/

Normally you'd use 406 to indicate that the sever can't produce a representation of the requested resource that is acceptable to the client. For instance, the client might have declared that it prefers content in French (via Accept-Language) but it's only available in English and for whatever reason the server doesn't default to it. Then 406 would be appropriate.

From my experience.
Apex legends is a dx11 game that is particularly bad on arc.
For some reason the clocks just keep dipping. Maybe it's waiting in some bad Async implementations.
I think GTA 5 is dx10, the performance at least used to be bad, I haven't tried it post driver patch, but it supposedly did get some improvements.
Beamng drive is dx10 or dx11. I was getting 40-50 fps stock. With dxvk DLLs I can get 200 fps. It's a single player game so I can add these dxvk DLLs without worrying about anticheats.

Dx10 never got picked up widely.
Dx11 was fairly popular. But short lived since lower level APIs were known to be the future. Which lead to AMD Mantle / Vulkan / DX12 APIs.

Depends on what you are printing.
Fully printed guns (where even the barrel is printed) don't hold up after one shot

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90897437
>I have no idea how to add "texture" that's more than just retriggering different parts of the break.
Do you mean like when you get a time-streatched amen snare?

There's a couple of different ways to do it. A somewhat dirty way to do it is by interpolating the slice command on a fast ticked pattern. This is how you would have done it in an old school tracker. Other things you could do is use a retrigger command. In FT2 it was either R00 or E90, not sure what it is in Renoise. This would give a more high pitched glitch-y noise. A third old-school way would have been to edit the samples into multiple chunks and then have them looped with a very short loop. Lastly for something more modern, Renoise has it's repeater effect that you can use.

>Also, how do I do the dnb staple of retriggered sample getting louder with every hit?
That's pretty easy, you could just insert the desired value in the volume column. So for every snare hit in a sequence would be raised a value or so.

I just took the Live 10/Max 8 envelope and removed all the envelope stuff but kept the mappers.

The X in the square buttons toggles between using the global random value (same for all the mappers) or its own unique random value.

READ THE WIKI! & help by contributing:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server

>NAS Case Guide. Feel free to add to it:
https://wiki.installgentoo.com/wiki/Home_server/Case_guide

/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. Know all about NAS? Learn virtualization. Spun up some VMs? Learn about networking by standing up a OPNsense/PFsense box and configuring some VLANs. There's always more to learn and chances to grow. Think you’re god-tier already? Setup OpenStack and report back.

>What software should I run?
Install Gentoo. Or whatever flavour of *nix is best for the job or most comfy for you. Jellyfin/Plex to replace Netflix, Nextcloud to replace Googlel, Ampache/Navidrome to replace Spotify, the list goes on. Look at the awesome self-hosted list and ask.

>Why should I have a home server?
/hsg/ is about learning and expanding your horizons. De-botnet your life. Learn something new. Serving applications to yourself, your family, and your frens feels good. Put your /g/ skills to good use for yourself and those close to you. Store their data with proper availability redundancy and backups and serve it back to them with a /comfy/ easy to use interface.

Server tips: https://anonbin.io/?1759c178f98f6135#CzLuPx4s2P7zuExQBVv5XeDkzQSDeVkZMWVhuecemeN6

Cheap disks: https://shucks.top/ & https://diskprices.com/

>>90888741
port forward 3389 to your device
RDP is pretty secure (encrypted and password protected) so it should be *fine* but you would probably want to set up a VPN if you want to be even more secure.

bear in mind windows RDP does NOT use ANY hardware accelerated rendering (and there is no way to make RDP do this, either), so over longer distances and slower connections it can become unbearably slow, and I find sometimes I need to actually start loading something, close the connection and then reopen it for it to actually update the application window.
If you need to actually "use" your windows box remotely, consider a VNC solution. RDP is only really useful on local networks and for very quick or simple tasks like starting/stopping services

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90891920
they cover how to use the commands but theres probably a lot you need to learn about magnetic tape as well, like conceptually, to be able to put those commands to good use; i'm guessing you know little to nothing. but for the most part you can get by with just rewinding the tape, tar'ing a bunch of shit onto it and then again using tar to read it back. but if you want to look at individual files, compression modes, spanning across multiple tapes, etc you're going to need to learn about how data is actually stored on tape.
bear in mind noone outside of enterprises with deep pockets has used tape on a computer since never, and the difference between them and you is you can't afford the software that makes it easy; but you can learn how to do it the hard way, which involves knowing how tapes work, and mt and tar.

don't forget to store your tapes in a cool, dry place. my preferance is in food-safe, sealable tupperware containers with some silica gel in the top shelf of my kitchen pantry. it's also worth getting a cleaning tape and running that through once a month. they are usually good for about 50 uses, so like 3-4 years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90897273

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90898878
They will have a few redundant load balancers in-front of those servers, and when a request is received its sent to one of those servers round-robin to be handled. When a server stops passing health checks, the load balancer will stop sending requests to it until it recovers.

You can have a cluster of 3 pcs working on lots of smaller jobs, but one large serial task generally can't be split between several processors.

You mean 3D games? You're not going to be doing any of that over RDP. You need an actual streaming solution optimized for the task to play games remotely, basic bitch remote desktop is for shit like using desktop applications, not real-time gaming.

>>90899500
>over a local network.
yeah that's exactly what I said
>is only really useful on local networks
once you leave the local network, the delay between the host and the thing that renders the host (the client) becomes so great that trying to render even opening the start menu can take upwards of 30 seconds. this is because all rendering done is software rendering, and a good chunk of it is done on the client while connected to the session - if both your host and your client have great internet speeds, it's not that bad, but if not...
I frequently find myself having to disconnect to let the host render a menu, and then reconnect because the 15 seconds of time that takes is genuinely faster than waiting for the menus to render while connected.
>and is vastly superior to VNC
how so anyway? I've found VNC to have much higher bitrates and be overall much clearer than RDP, even on RDP's highest quality settings. The only thing VNC doesn't really do is allow captive cursors in 3d applications, although I'm sure some clients have ways to enable that.

Is it compressed video, as in it's actually using a video codec? I was under the impression VNC did not do this, which is exactly why it's slow. Actual streaming solutions which send a real video stream usually work much better, but require higher bandwidth to do it at good quality. I was under the impression solutions like VNC send chunks of image when they change and any compression applied is only rudimentary, at most to the content being sent and not in an actual video stream.
>Again it comes back to the software rendering happening on the client side.
You keep mentioning this as a downside, but I don't see exactly how or why. It's probably going to take less data to tell the client "draw a grey rectangle of a particular size at coords x,y" than it would to render the rectangle locally, then capture the image and send the entire modified area over the network. This seems like an entirely reasonable way of doing things if the goal is 2D desktop work, with the disadvantage that it's obviously not tenable for high performance 3D.

I have never seen this sort of delay that you're experiencing with RDP. I even connected to one of my VMs from my phone over cellular (4G) and it was fine. There's a perceptible delay (I would guess it's in the ~250ms range, well under 1s anyway) so it's not particularly responsive but the actual drawing happens quickly even over such a shitty connection.

>Real shame NVIDIA is killing their streaming platform
Are they actually killing it or just removing it from Shield TV on Android? I don't remember reading anything about the functionality being taken out on the PC side.
>steam remoteplay as an alternative, which is objectively terrible.
Works fairly well in my experience, but it has the typical problems of Valve software of not being particularly polished and as far as I'm aware it does software capture + hardware encode only, which hurts its performance at high resolution.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90898924
No SMR drives and ZFS doesn't mix well. For one thing lord help you if you ever do a drive replacement. The resliver time takes ages compared to a normal drive. For another due to how the drive is you'll get random CHKSUM errors tossed at you during scrubs. SMART can say "drive healthy" and you'll still get them at random times. And yes swapping out the cable (if you can) does little good.Still happens. But for all it's quirks the drives do the job. Just you have to clear out the errors and keep backups just in case (which you should do anyway). If I'd have to do it again I'd go with another brand. Note: CHKSUM errors aren't bad in an of themselves long as redundancy exists (Raid Z2 at minimum). Thing you have to watch for is read and write errors. I bought these drives in 2019. 6x of them. Only replaced one, rest are going good. I didn't know they were SMR till it was to late.

Ok so you've got a 2Gbps connection to your router from the server. But that'll do you little good if the rest of the links going to the router are only 1Gbps. So basically half of that 2Gbps is going unused. To make the most of it all links in the chain must be 2Gbps. Your desktop, any other servers, etc. So now instead of a single ethernet cable running whereever now you have to run two of them as well as install another nic in the desktop or server that also supports link ag. Double the work involved. V.s a simple nic swap to 10Gbps or 2.5 Gbps with maybe a cable upgrade if it's not rated for speeds past 1 Gbps.
