>>90920975
high capacity hdds can reach 50 degrees at normal operations, if you put 20 of them in a case with limited airflow and cooling (ie, the case in the OP) you reach temlreatures much higher than any single GPU can put out. a 4090 under load is producing up to 100 degrees on the chip, but comparatively very little of that gets into the rest of the system because of thr massive cooler. HDDs don't have big heatsinks, so when they get hot they stay hot and it becomes more difficult to cool them because of their thermal mass vs dissapation. they might not consome much energy, so heating up doesn't happen quickly, but they will stay hotter for longer and are harder to cool because of that and the lack of direct dissapation. they are full of air which also doesn't help, as air is an insulator not a conductor.

now you densly pack a bunch of these devices that maintain more heat for longer into a cranped corner with little airflow, and you get high tempreatures. the low power draw doesn't matter when you aren't able to cool it directly. why do you think sandpaper gets very warm from even a few light rubs on wood or steel? it's not a lot of energy, but theres also nothing to dissapate that energy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90922144
It's a mixed bag. I read the privacy policies on each site and it seems some will permanently delete your data (they claim), which is good. It also seems some will remove it from their index but still retain it so they don't create a new person if some new record in the future that relates to you is obtained. Which seems reasonable as long as they aren't sharing the data with third parties. For example, White Pages is a good example of this. Overall, I think it's a good idea to go through all of the major data brokers and remove anything you can find regardless of what they do. At the very least it gets your shit off Google and other search engines as about half of those I exampled publicly dispaly everything about you on the surface web (ie Radaris, Instant Checkmate, White Pages, Spokeo, Voter Records, TruePeopleSearch, etc...). I think the biggest thing that's helped recently is CCPA as many of those businesses are scared of being sued and there's been increased awareness about them since the John Oliver segment last year.

imo it comes down to what you want to do, do you want to make a game or are you more interested in writing an engine.

If your main creative concern is making games then you should focus on using existing tech and develop your programming skills as a side product. (while also upskilling in tech that will more likely land you work in modern game dev)

Hobbyist programmers aren't normally concerned with reinventing the wheel, you aren't trying to innovate over existing technology you're having fun and upskilling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's a really bad idea for several reasons. The biggest is underestimating how much time you need to finish a decent game, much less an engine. You were probably thinking of making one at some point, right? Well take that estimate and multiply it by 50. Yes, no exaggeration, it's simply that big of a project. And estimating the complexity of an engine is 10 times worse. Factor in limited motivation and you're really only left with 2 realistic choices: never making a game ever or using all the shortcuts you can. Yes, you're probably imagining how easy it is to write a 20 liner to render an image or a 40 liner for displaying a 3d model in opengl and thinking "durrr it can't be THAT bad". But it is. It's hard to explain. You don't think it be like that but it do. Another reason is underestimating how fast modern hardware is. On one hand, you probably share the notion that modern software is too bloated and can be done better. But you're again forced to make a choice here: spending years learning to optimize your shit and probably lose interest in the whole thing thus, again, never making anything, or making SOMETHING that actually works at full speed on 95% machines anyway, within a reasonable time frame. One more is underestimating how flexible modern game engines are. You can really do any game you want in them. You just need to learn if you can't see that.
Basically, it's an issue of making actually realistic choices that have actually good odds of coming true. Obviously, in a perfect world, you would make everything from scratch, and your ebin multiplayer open world harvest moon/pokemon roguelike with voxel graphics and procedural everything would run on a toaster and you'd be crowned king of videogames. But given that making GOOD games requires you to have not only proficiency in programming (however small) but also a means to make assets, your ability to do so from scratch is nil since you're only human, with limited time, ability and motivation.

I think people often conflate the concept of making a game engine for your game(s) with making a generalized game engine that could be used to make a number of different games.
When in reality, it just has to work for what you intend to do and can be much more direct and straightforward than going through a number of intermediate abstractions (which you'd either have to write or find).
Not to say there can't be any generality or reusability, but you can break components up into much smaller libraries and responsibilities.

Relevant Jon Blow rant about some generalized entity system that you'd have to learn and build around instead of just directly doing what you need for your 1 game instead.
https://youtu.be/dS6rCaDSwW8?t=515

>Why does everyone say not to make your own game engine?
The arguments on both sides are usually retarded. The nodevs in favor of using engines say "don't reinvent the wheel," and the nodevs on the other side play internet tough guy that anything other than hand-crafted assembler means you aren't a real programmer.

Reality is different for every case. There are pros and cons of each approach as well as various degrees in between.

>wouldn't it make more sense for me to create my own engine?
You need to handle graphics, sound, I/O, and game state. You probably want to use libraries for at least the first three. Maybe you want also libraries for mechanics like physics and collision detection. You need tools for creating assets and content.

Something like Unity tries to be an all-in-one package for everyone, including teams that have both experienced programmers and artists and designers more accustomed to traditional gui tools like photoshop and blender. Godot is like a budget Unity. But you're going to inherit a lot of complexity that is very likely to slow you down once you get past the first few days of spawning a skeleton project and you have to coerce your ideas into the features provided by the engine.

>>90897348
>Cakez
You're speaking as if he's going to go through the same process again for his next game. What these discussions usually neglect to consider is that time spent on the initial setup/learning/architecture is not the same at all as the bulk of the game development time.

Most kinds of games take at least a few years to make no matter what tool you use, in that grand scheme of things the time spent on the engine isn't that big at all. And once you've made an engine, you can easily re-use parts of it so the time spent on the engine is significantly lower than the first time around. From what I understand Cakez learned to make and made his own Vulkan renderer, it seems tedious and unnecessary but he won't have to go through that process all over again for his next game. He may modify or improve it but the work is mostly one-off and already done.

Having your own engine can in some cases speed up development because you're far more familiar with all the different parts and can more easily rewrite any part of it. Arguably learning to make an engine mandates that you get good at programming, which also makes you progress faster.

Great post. A big question for a new dev is whether you will learn more by getting up and running quickly with an engine, or starting from scratch. It's going to take a long time either way. Some people are more likely to give up or get lost if they spend too much time on foundations.
They might spend weeks building basic components with no real vision of how to even get a full game working. Others will get frustrated and bored using a game engine, when they hit a wall where they have some problem and progress gets stalled entirely while they comb through reams of docs and discussions and asset store tools pages trying to find the best solution to a specific and maybe uncommon problem. Then the demoralizing process of choosing between 2-3 suboptimal solutions and adapting your game design to better fit the expectations of premade tools.

>>90887575
What people mean when they say this is you will almost always be able to make your game much faster if you go with an off-the-shelf engine.
>Wouldn't this make me an all around better programmer?
Yeah it probably would. It would also teach you a lot about graphics, sound, input, collision detection, scene management and so on. If your goal is to learn, or if you are doing it for fun, then go for it.
Godot makes it easy to have a somewhat hybrid approach. Most of the vanilla engine features are implemented in module directories which can simply be deleted from the source tree to strip the engine of features you don't care about (VR, file format support, gdscript, etc) and you can implement your own modules however you need. This is great if you want a jumping off point to implement specific low level features but don't want to deal with the really tedious boilerplate stuff like input handling or window management.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>90900644
>You find bugs in your engine by using it to make your game
This is why in-house engines designed to make a specific games are a nightmare to use elsewhere. E.g. the source engine is full of hacky workarounds for specific Valve titles in engine code. Frostbite has a huge reputation for being a pain in the ass because DICE develops it for their style of games, then EA forces it's other subsidiaries to use it (see Mass Effect Andromeda).
General purpose engines don't have this problem because they need to accommodate a huge amount of games simultaneously, so features are usually introduced in a way that isn't tailored to any specific game - that's the game code's responsibility.
General purpose engines tend to be rigorously documented as well, so it's easy to figure out if a function's behaviour meets the spec.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Games are more complex now that they used to be and are expected to run on a lot of different platforms. Nowadays you can't get away with just drawing triangles, camera culling and a simple distance-based collision system. That means that an engine that would provide you with similar or better functionality than an existing one, even if just for your game, is very complex to do and to get it right.

So if your goal is to make a game, why spend the time on making an engine? You are going to have your hands full anyway. You do not code a compiler or a web server when you want to make a web application, so why should you do the same with a game?

You should clearly state your purpose.
If it is learning for the sake of learning, sure, go for it, even if it just a very simple engine where you draw a couple of cubes.
If it is learning to potentially get in the industry, it may help but your time would be better spent learning to use an existing one.
If it is to actually make a game, then definitely do not roll your own.

>turing complete so in theory you can create anything
No, you can't. Turing completeness just means that you can compute anything if you had infinite time, infinite space and were willing to rewrite everything.
Not a very relevant concept when talking about video games as you do not infinite time or space and writing large amounts of custom code would defeat the purpose of using someone else's code in the first place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90887575
>Why does everyone say not to make your own game engine?
Mixture of insecurity (they're too dumb to make an engine and upset that anyone else would) and lack of knowledge / awareness of the game industry.

If you look at the most successful solo- or very-small indie games, they're generally made by engine devs. Minecraft. Factorio. Dwarf Fortress. Starsector. Stardew Valley. Etc. All made with custom engines. Yes, most indie games are made with public engines, but most games are retarded shitty asset flips that sell next to nothing or maybe hit meme status for a while, but have no staying power because they aren't actually good. Use of public engines for successful indie games tends to be higher for bigger studios, but for the really small teams, the winners are almost universally engine devs, perhaps in large part because these successful games tend to involve unique and complex mechanics.

There is a case to be made that if you're making a game with a paradigm very similar to the traditional action game - a shooter, action RPG, whatever - that Unreal or Unity are good choices. But if you're making anything different, especially strategy/simulation, it's pretty clear that public engines are a horribly bad choice and you should make your own instead. The amount of work you'll take hacking Unreal into something that can be used for a strategy game far outweighs the work it would take just making your own engine.

On top of this, for simulation-heavy games, keep in mind that Unreal and Unity are all about grafix; their CPU performance is pretty shit and they have terrible multithreading; if you're making a game that involves a lot of CPU work you WILL get better performance with a custom engine.

People say oh, you'll spend so long on your engine, you won't make a game!!! but the reality seems to be the other way around. If you want to be the next Toady, you'd best be enginedevving. If you want to make platformer slop nobody will buy, install Unity.

>In my experience SSD's through SATA dont seem to make that much of a difference
Depends. If you encrypt your hard drive (as you always should, on laptops at least), the difference is quite big in my experience.

If you don't use encryption, then no, the difference is not that great, as you said.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>90915106
>X220 vs T420
yeah that's a hard decision.
I'd actually recommend the T410 instead with a 16:10 screen. The T series is a nice size but the T420 has a 16:9 screen which feels like wasted space. It feels small.
I don't have experience with the X220 but I've used the X60 which has a 4:3 screen which I think is better than 16:9, and maybe even better than 16:10. It's okay for light use here and there, but I'd prefer something bigger for everyday or long-term use, like the T series. The X220 has a 16:9, so I'd imagine it would be super thin.
Also the X series is really expensive. The X220 is 100$ at the cheapest if you get lucky and even then you're going to be missing parts. There's plenty that go for 150-300.
Meanwhile, you can get the T420 under 100$ easily. You could even look into other options around the same price like the T420i which has a slightly less powerful CPU, T420p (performance) has a slighty more powerful cpu and T420s(slim). I think some people say that the T420s sucks though so not entirely sure about that one, but it seems fine.
If you don't care about corebooting, It's probably best to go for X301(slightly bigger screen) or X201. (Maybe the X300 is not a bad price, not sure.)

For what it's worth, here's how I got determining whether x and y are inside the bigger circle

for y in range(diameter + 1):
    lineWidth = math.floor(math.sqrt(pow(radius,2) - pow(y - radius,2)))
    for x in range(diameter + 1):
        if (x >= (radius - lineWidth) and x <= (lineWidth + radius)):
            yinYangOutput.write(".")
        else:
            yinYangOutput.write(" ")
    yinYangOutput.write("\n")

def is_in_circle(center, radius, point):
    return (center.x - point.x) ** 2 + (center.y - point.y) ** 2 <= radius ** 2

>>90920107
I'd just like to interject for a moment. What you're referring to as Linux,
is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I've recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux.
Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component
of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell
utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day,
without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU
which is widely used today is often called "Linux", and many of its users are
not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project.

There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a
part of the system they use. Linux is the kernel: the program in the system
that allocates the machine's resources to the other programs that you run.
The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself;
it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is
normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system
is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called "Linux"
distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux.

posts.name: dead
posts.com:
>>90895213
I buy only mystery ranch as you can see.

My work daily driver is the 3 way. It's perhaps a bit fat but it's well made and thought of. I have had it carry three laptops but usually with me is my work macbook pro, a lot of cables for different things, a gozero sherpa powerbank with 60W of type c power output, a mouse and whatever shit I might need. It can expand by opening up a zipper that compresses it so I can put in a jacket if I need to but I try to keep it just for the computer and accessories, everything I need and might need. it has backpack straps too that hide in the back. Useful if it turns out I have to carry it for a longer time.

The 2 day assault is my daily driver backpack when I'm bringing my personal PC and camera with me. It's very EDC focused so it has a good padded laptop pocket with easy access and a lot of other storage options. I wish it had a larger capacity but for what it is, and for the price, it's a winner. It hardly shows any signs of wear even though I've used it a lot.

The largest is the Komodo Dragon and it's great for when I'm travelling. It's more mil gear so it doesn't have a laptop pocket but I don't tend to use this backpack when I travel with a laptop. It can carry it, but this is more like a do-it-all for hiking and stuff. I like to use this when riding with my motorcycle as I often need the capacity. As for quality compared to the 2 day assault, there is not much difference. It's stronger and bigger but how well the 2 day performs, it's hard to justify buying this. But then again, I buy it once and for life, this thing isn't going to go bad before I do.

If you are someone like >>90895213 just do yourself a service and don't buy this shit, it'll just break and wear down and you'll be buying the same shit over and over and you can never trust it to not fail. That's the biggest difference to me, I can 100% rely on my gear.

Mystery Ranch ain't the only company making good backpacks, but they are good.

You can do it "function" by "function" and test it. So you can have 1 C function that is converted from assembly and combine that with the existing assembly. 0.0 multiplier is applied after transformers. Transformers, in a nutshell, is a neural network that enriches every word in text with information about other words. So cat is enriched with knowledge about jelly, jelly with knowledge about cat, then then jelly is zeroed out.

>>90924058
Go to Dynamic Prompts, switch it from "none" to "X/Y" Plot.

For the "X" plot, choose "Sampler", since what you want to test is Samplers.
Then type in the Samplers you to test, verbatim. So: DDIM, Euler, Euler A, DPM++ 2M Karras etc.
What's important is that you put a COMMA after every sampler. The comma lets SD know how to separate the concept being tested.

And that's it, you click run. And then SD will test your prompt with all of the samplers you've chosen.

But what about the other X/Y plot options? Same idea, really. Choose what you want to test, and then separate them with commas. So if you wanted to test steps: 20, 40, 60, 100 etc. If you want to test checkpoints (models): model1, model2, model3. If you want to check CFG: 1, 5, 10 etc. Denoising?: 3, 5, 9 etc.

If you want to test two concepts simultaneously: Put one test in the X plot and another in the Y plot. (Like I do in pic related).

>>90924058
The only X/Y option that differs from this formula is "Prompt S/R".

Prompt S/R stands for "Search and Replace". With Prompt S/R, you can dynamically change your prompt through a test.

What do I mean by this? Let's say you want to test the effects of 10 different artists on your prompt. With Prompt S/R, you can tell SD to test all of them in a sequence -- test this artist, then test this artist, then test this artist basically.

How do you do this? It's easy. Identify the word or sequence of words in your prompt that you want to change. Put these words in the X/Y chart under Prompt S/R. Then put a COMMA to separate it from the next phrase of words you want to test.

For example, in pic related, the original prompt ONLY has Edmund Leighton. I want to test other artists, so I put Edmund Leighton in the prompt S/R first followed by a comma, then an artist, then a comma. Repeat until I'm satisifed.

>>90922061
Styles are a bit looser. I don't have much practice with them (I want subjects first, then I can worry about style once I have covered the important ones).
But generally seems higher network dimensions are better at transferring style. Never do dreambooth style for...styles, and be mindful of overfitting. I suggest starting at 160 net dim and if it's too weak, try raising it in intervals of 32 and see how it compares.
